title: Insect filter for Schuberth C3 helmet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Schuberth C3 helmet has two 15mm (about 19/32") holes for its ventilation system on the inside that have a direct connection to a large air intake on top.  
That's a good idea, because your head gets cooled in summer, but not carried out the best way, because they forgot to add a fly screen between the shell and the cushioning and therefore now and then you get insects in between your head and the helmets shell, and sometimes they survive...  
So I made this thing to prevent them from coming in. :)

I couldn't think of an easy way to provide this as an STL or such, sorry!  
The GCode has been manually modified and optimized for 0,3mm layer height and 0,42mm string thickness.

title: Kossel top spool with skateboard bearing

description.text:
Printed great. Works wonderfully. 100 infill .2 layer

See comments for updated notes.

I didn't like the idea of using a printed bearing due to noise and rolling resistance, and had a skateboard bearing laying around from some project a long time ago. I took the frame work and added a small cylinder 8mm in diameter to fit into the skateboard bearing, and the shelf below it supports the weight on the inner race. I then used the file for a spool hub that accepted a skateboard bearing. I am going to test print now and I'll see if it all works and if I need to tweak the file.

This is a replacement knob for IMAGE brand pole mount speaker tripod stands. You need the old knob to get the steel bolt that was molded inside the original knob. The bolt in mine was a M6-1.0 x 60mm completely threaded.

90

Notes:

I used PLA and it worked out nicely.

Part required some sanding to remove sharp edges, since it's a hand know you don't want sharp edges.

I cleaned up the opening for the bolt head and threads with some small files. The bolt head was heated with a heat gun and set firmly into place with a hammer and steel point to prevent it from coming out.
Totally designed in Tinkercad by taking measurements from the original. It's a knob close is good enough, I'm not out to duplicate an injection molding machine.

remixed_from.title: 8mm Self aligning Igus bearing vertical or horizontal mount

description.text: Remix of the 8mm Self aligning Igus bearing by mska. Removed the rotating part to improve accuracy, took out the undercut around the bearing support which made it weak, moved the mounting holes so they can be mounted with bolts or self tapping screws from either side, Rotated the part so it would print without supports. Cleaned up the file and fixed a few surfaces. Also added an extended version. Put these on the smooth rods and mark your hole placement then drill. You can use super glue to line these up then drill the holes after so they do not bind. Check out my other designs for more interesting useful things!
Downloaded the files, cleaned them up and mixed the parts together to improve the idea and make it better.

title: Detailed Calibration Tower
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made yet another temperature tower because I couldn't gauge how smaller details were affected with other temperature towers on Thingiverse. Printed in PLA, it only uses about 4 grams of filament.

Each section is 10mm tall

This tower has the following features:

  • Small text to see fine details
  • Thin walls
  • Thin cylinder and a thin angled piece
  • A thin cone. In the design, the cone goes all the way up the top of the level. Your slicer will make it shorter depending on nozzle width
  • Bridges
  • Overhang at 45 degrees, 55 degrees, and 65 degrees
  • The side with circles inside of rectangles shows extruded and embossed geometry. The rectangles are embossed or extruded, the circle parts are level with the main wall. The left column is extruded and the right column is embossed

title: Simpler Daniel Christiansen Differential Motion Radial Bearing (X55)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Thank you for checking this out! I hope you show me yours after you make it!

Experimental Roller Separation Anti-Friction Bearing. It worked for me on my printer, but I haven't tried it on any other. This is not intended for any scale adjustments. Print at your own risk, but I am 95% confident it will work for you. Please give me feedback on how I can improve it for you, and I will update it as soon as I can.

These are the essential STL's for making my X55 Radial bearing, modeled after the invention of Daniel Christiansen.

Recommended Minimum Infill & Print Settings & Required Quantities: (Expert 3D printerinos and printerinas should play with the settings to their heart's content. )

(x7) Main Rollers: 0%.

(x7) Spacer Rollers: 0-20%. (Doesn't change print speed too much)

(x2) Concentor Collars: 10-20%. This part needs the strength.

(x1) Inner Sleeve: 10-20%. I printed at 20%, (SUPPORTS REQUIRED.)

(x1) Outer Sleeve: 10-20%. (SUPPORTS REQUIRED) Thicker bottoms and tops will allow you to bring this below 20%.

(x1) Assembly Jig: 0-20% The added resiliency will ensure a lasting part, and its sturdiness will aid in removal from the bed and additionally from the bearing once assembly is nearly complete.

INSTRUCTIONS:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jVG4iUOXRjM

CHANGE LOG:

3-29-2017: Reduced size of innermost diameter of outer sleeve by 0.1MM to reduce slippage. Also reduced size of End Cap inserting side to make it easier for assembly.

Also, check the blog for some pics and to stay up to date on what's going on next.
https://npg3d.blogspot.com/2017/03/x55-roller-bearing.html

comments.text: So I'm not the only one obsessing about low friction bearings that are 100% (or nearly 100%) 3D printed.  Same spirit, but different style. I've been playing around with low friction circulating ball bearings for nuts/threaded shafts.  I'm working on a general purpose SCAD file with lots of useful parameters.  Not quite done yet, but I can see that both of us can't help but make these things and fiddling with them whild waiting for web pages to load and such.  :-)  Way cool.
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: Woohoo! We looooooove bearings! This will be the year of the 3D printed bearing. They do make great fiddlers don't they?
comments.author: foxpup

comments.text: I can see from the patent diagram how this bearing could handle very large radial loads.  (not so much axial)  It seems to be only subtly different from the one you already made.  The whole thing about parts free rolling about inside and still not getting out of position is fascinating.  I keep finding myself wanting to use gear toothing to keep things in place but that makes for more demanding printing.  Lord knows I've printed a few absolutely solid herringbone planetary gear bearings that simply don't turn without destroying them. :-)  Later on I have made a rather nice central bearing for a high strength lazy Susan setup that I put 3d printers on top of.  Its a lot easier working on those things when you can just spin them around to get to their different parts. :-)  Never did upload it, perhaps I should.  At the time it didn't seem original enough and wasn't tested well enough for me to want to share, but it has been now. :-)  I guess we never really get too far from primitive man contemplating the wheel do we. :-)
comments.author: NPG3D

comments.text: Great at radial loads, and foregoes the cage by utilizing differential motion roller separation. That's why it is commonly referred to and compared to when regarding Christiansen's design, and why I decided to make it. However, I think Christiansen's design is much superior. That isn't surprising considering it was invented approximately 50 years later, and likely borrowed its principle of operation before advancing it. Christiansen's more advanced bearing (not the X55) can utilize semi-spherical knuckular flanges for nearly frictionless axial thrust capacity, and has features like oil filtration and more.

title: Decora 4 on/off wall switch with LEDs

description.text:
This is a remix of the Decora Blank by Corona688. This is also alternate design remix of my other 8 button switch http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2136094 . The circuit board for this design will also work for the 8 button wall switch design.

This is a design for a decora style 4 button on/off rocker switch with indicator LEDs for each row of buttons. This is a project I have been working on for a MySensors switch controller. Other information as well as the prototpe of this (prior to the 3D printed version) can be seen at:
https://forum.mysensors.org/topic/4317/us-decora-style-wall-switch/
The crossbar brace assembly for this model is used as a pivot for the rocker switches. The pivot is to prevent pressing both the on and the off buttons simultaneously. This is not a required piece for the switch to work, but it will give the switch a better feel.
The switch plate is designed to mount a 3cm x 7cm prototype or other circuit board similar to this:
https://console5.com/store/perforated-board-3cm-x-7cm.html
The circuit board is mounted using 2mm x 5mm self tapping screws. The switches used are 6mm x 6mm tactile switches with a switch height of 4.3mm to 5mm:
http://www.robotshop.com/en/sfe-mini-push-button-switch.html?gclid=CJyh2_fEq9ICFQEIaQodYO0LcA
The indicator LED holes are designed to hold any standard 3mm LED, though the hole size can be increased to fit larger LEDs if desired.

See my other switches I posted to get more information on the creation of these switches. You can also check out my blog post on my website that talks about how I created these. https://dan.bemowski.info/2017/06/11/my-start-into-open-source-hardware/

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used Cura to print this and used Support Type: Everywhere to prevent stringing.

The Design

The design of the buttons was based on the X10 XPT line of switches. The X10 line of switches do not have LED indicators like the ones I have added.

Other Electronics

The other electronics for this consist of two boards, the computer board and the power supply board. All 3 of the boards stack on top of each other for a slim design that fits inside a standard single gang wall box.

The main board is the computer board based on a 3.3v arduino pro mini. This also uses an nRF24L01+ radio module and is set up to run the MySensors protocol. The setup is simply a transmitter that talks to the MySensors gateway and through macros or scenes can be set up to control any number of lights or appliances.

The last board in the setup is the power supply board. This is based off of the HLK-PM01 power module which converts 120/240 volts down to 5 volts. For safety a standard 1 amp mini fuse, an MOV, and a thermal cutoff fuse are used in the design.

Conclusion

Though my design of this is for use with my MySensors automation setup, the basic switch design can be set up to work in any number of different configurations. Check my MySensors forum topic on this switch and see the original prototype that I built before I got my 3D printer. https://forum.mysensors.org/topic/4317/us-decora-style-wall-switch

I would LOVE to hear of others using this design and how you used it. Post a comment and let me know what great things you have created with this.

More about me

For more information about me and other projects and things by me, take a look at my websirte at https://dan.bemowski.info/

title: Economic 5DollarFilament spool adapter for RepRapGuru Prusa i3 v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The spool holder which mounts onto the back of the RepRapGuru Prusa i3 acrylic frame isn't compatible with ProtoParadigm's 5 dollar filament, and I didn't want to print out a large custom spool to fit over the 5DF spools.

I had a PVC pipe that measured 1 1/16 inches in diameter, so I designed something to take advantage of that.

I don't know if the acrylic spool holder comes with other printers than the RepRapGuru, but if it does, this spool adapter should work just as well for those.

Update 2017/04/10: Added pvc-rod-spacer to fix a problem with the arms of the ProtoParadigm spool catching on the screws protruding on the inside of the printer's acrylic spool holder. Also added a solid rod model so you can set your own wall thickness.

1. Print two of the 5DF_stabilizer-remix, and attach them to the spool as shown in the original 5DF Spool Stabilizer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1397920
  2. Print two of the PVC rod mounts, and slip them onto the tabs which are in the middle of the sides of the existing acrylic spool holder.
  3. Print two of the pvc-rod-spacers.
  4. If you have a 1 1/16" diameter PVC rod, or if you purchase one, cut it to size (about 112 mm long). Otherwise, print out pvc-rod-hollow, or pvc-rod-solid if you want to set your own top/bottom/wall thickness and infill.
  5. Slide the rod through the spool and spacers, with a spacer on each side of the spool. Place the assembly on the rod mounts.

First of all, why would you upload a suppressor design without first testing it, knowing that people will use this with a real

comments.text:
I am not a lawyer but, to my knowledge in the US, suppressors are regulated the same as machine guns.
Printing one of these without first applying for an NFA tax stamp is a felony and punishable by up to 10 years in jail and up to a $10,000 fine.
Tread lightly friends...
comments.author: Actionhank

comments.text:
Yes and no. If the actual use is to put the suppressor on a .22 then YES you definitely have to pay the $200 NFA tax stamp and it must have a serial number.
If you are printing it to put on an airsoft gun or a cosplay gun, then you do not have to pay the $200 NFA tax stamp.
comments.author: Actionhank

comments.text:
No, I don't think that's correct.
By that rationale it should ok for me to make or buy a functioning metal suppressor with no tax stamp as long as I promised that I would only put it on an airsoft/cosplay gun.
comments.author: bxmas13

comments.text: This is not entirely the case. The suppressor was designed for a .22 caliber projectile weapon. Firearm is not specifically stated, so .22 caliber pellet guns can easily be claimed to be what it's used for. The baffles don't need to be removed for an air gun.

title: Shorter 40mm fan shroud for monoprice maker select

description.text:
This is an approximate copy of the original fan shroud that comes with the monoprice maker select mk2. Except it is slightly shorter (in case you've been having problems with the shroud dragging on your print).

After I upgraded to an all metal hotend, I started having this dragging problem so I replaced the shroud with this.

comments.text:
Thanks, I had the same problem with the all metal hot end. tip for those planning the upgrade: print this first! I ended up removing the metal shroud and temporarily securing the fan with electrical tape while I printed the new shroud.
As a plus, the new shroud weighs only 1/4 ounce (after sanding the bottom smooth) as compared to the 1 1/2 ounces of the original metal shroud.

author: cncmodel

title: Wanhao Duplicator I3 PVC Style Z-Brace and extras

description.text:
UPDATE!!! IT'S FINISHED (KIND OF)!!!!!!! Some parts require dremeling for proper fitting, but I managed to get mine assembled fairly easy, and I'm in love with this look. Adds bulk, plus general appeal to the machine to me. I love pvc and am very happy with the results.

To start off, im extremely new to 3D imaging, 3D printing, and any type of cad style programs. Never before have I used one prior to about a month ago, and I am entirely self taught. With that said, I do not think I know everything by any stretch of the imagination. The main point in me joining this page is seeking help in my designs from individuals that out class me, and to network with those individuals. This is my first big design I've been working on that'll benefit others as well as myself.

Now onto the design. I've seen alot of the metal rod z-braces, and wanted to design something to give my wanhao duplicator i3 a little bit different look from the rest, so I designed what I will be calling "The Roll Cage". When it is fully assembled and attached to the machine, it will act as a great support for the main tower to prevent forward and back swaying without having to settle for the only way out. I personally love working with pvc, and that's what inspired this style brace system. These are the fixed versions of the v1 design I did as seen in the pics, and is made to use 3/4" pvc with. Currently all parts will fit with minor dremel work to clean up some edges of screw slots as it is a snug tight fit. I've added in slots to allow some up and down play. I will update pics as soon as I add in the pvc. Should give a great look to the machine when finished. The first version needed some minor tweaking, and will continue to grow and change into what you see in the files and very soon to come pictures.

I've also added every file attached to any upgrade you see on my machine. They're one's I've dug and dug and dug through countless files looking for ideals parts, and these are the ones I ended up with. I'll be designing my own filament guide that is a bit closer to the tower, and simple quick glue stick holder that'll snap onto the top of the tower, along with my own tool holder that holds what I consider the essentials (a caliper needs a spot on a tool holder more than scissors IMO and a hook on the end of the scrapper holder seems to be somewhat essential for me).

comments.text: IT'S FINISHED. I updated all the pics to show their finished and installed printed parts after the file.
comments.author: carternick01

comments.text: Can you post links to all the attachments to your hot-end and the other "things"?  Some of that I recognize, but some of that is new to me.  I have some neon green PLA that I'm going to be using for a setup similar to this.

Gave a great look to the machine while hiding all those ugly wires, and leaving the filament feed still easily accessible. I also have a few more I'll be adding on such as a y-axis support.

comments.text: Thanks. I am on my phone and can't get to the files but I look forward to checking it out tomorrow. I should be through with a couple of orders by Tuesday and start in on mods to the printer.

comments.text: They did require supports. The extruder cover will require almost as much support as there is actual print, so lots of cleanup after it finished, but the end result of this particular extruder cover to me is well worth every bit of it. I'll hopefully have some more green PLA tomorrow and be able to run off the supports, and assemble it. I'll be sure to make big updates to easily follow.
comments.author: djeaton

comments.text: I'm wondering if I that extruder cover will even work or is even needed on my Plus model.
comments.author: carternick01

comments.text: Hey man, looked closely at a plus model, and it'd primarily be for cosmetic's on it. Nothing to really tuck or hide away on the plus unlike all the excess wiring and stuff they put on the top of the extruder on base models.
comments.author: djeaton

comments.text: I'm not 100% on that. The main thing I liked about the extruder cover is it's ability to cover the loose wires and keep them nice a tucked away, and I respect the designer for the slit that allows the extruder to still do 100% of it's normal functioning, even as far as it's retraction all the way to the top for cooling. It also doubles as a side fan cover for the direct mounted fan as well, which was something else I was looking to print, so served a dual purpose for my needs. Also, it was maybe my 10th print ever, so it was a good test for me to see if I could tackle a piece a little larger than a key chain, lol. The best purpose based upgrades I've put in would be the bed leveling thumbwheels, and the 40mm fan duct.
comments.author: djeaton

comments.text: Even if all it did was protect those fine wires going to the thermistore, it is probably worth the time to print it out.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner of course.... the center uses 2 standard 608z skateboard bearings or similar (22 mm x 7 mm) stacked back to back. Used an old pencil drawing as inspiration that typically keeps me occupied when i sit and doodle; and has for many years. Most likely picked the shape up from a old math class eons ago.

Hope you enjoy, hard let me know if I screwed it up anywhere my eyes hurt after staring at it for a while!

Version 1 has more faces than version 2; also version one the bearings sit outside the frame intentionally.

Version 4- added some extra bearings for weight and longer spinning - same size as the others 7mm x 22mm. If you print it standing up it yields good results with a raft and supports. Might have to clean inside the bearing housing a bit or scale it up to 101% depending on your printer. It's a bit delicate when its done so use caution when installing bearings.

title: Legend of Zelda - A Link to the Past Plaque
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I drew this from the Legend of Zelda - a Link to the Past (my most favoritest game series ever) many moons ago. Now that I have a 3D printer, I figured why not reinvent it as a 3D print?

In all honesty, I have not yet printed it, but I plan on printing it soon. As soon as I do, I will upload photos. I will say that it tests as a water-tight solid under Google Sketchup and is reported as manifold under Slic3r. Until I print this, I am not sure how the 3D extruded text will come out, so I have included both models with and without the text. If you print this, be sure to upload photos of yours.

No supports, brims or rafts are needed. The default size is 183.6mm by 135mm x 10mm.

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 mk2 Yi Sport Camera holder

title: Prusa i3 MK2 GoPro Session Mount (longer)

description.text:
This is a Remix of the original "Prusa i3 mk2 Yi Sport Camera holder" which you can find here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704137

Since I wanted to attach my Gopro Session to the Prusa Printer I designed a new camera bed. It is designed such that the Gopro Session fits just tight and kind of 'clicks' into it.

As well as the bed I remixed the original "sliding_bracket.stl" to be about 20mm longer. Therefore you don't have to worry about your extruder crashing into your camera anymore! This change leads to the fact that you now actually see the bracket slider in the captured gopro image (See Image above). But of course you might just cut the relevant section of your videos/pictures in post video processing.

The remaining parts like Screw and Nut are the same. As mentioned in the original things comment, I also encountered some problems turning the screw into the nut, since it appeared to be designed very tight. Make sure to print the screw with high infill (I used 100%) and then repeat tighten and loosen the screw again and again until the screw is coming though the nut once. Finally you should be able to turn the screw just perfectly.

Have Fun!

print_settings.Notes:: I'd suggest printing it upside down from the way it was created.

description.text:
This was a part I mainly designed to force myself to learn some new things. In hindsight, it's probably not the most efficient design. If you're new to scad, and would like to learn more about rounding, I'd definitely suggest this tutorial http://www.iheartrobotics.com/2011/02/openscad-tip-round-2-of-3.html

I mainly uploaded it because I hadn't found any parametric ecig dust cap on here, and thought I might upload one.

Was a fairly easy print. I printed it in ABS(grey/glow-in-the-dark). If you're going to print it in ABS, I'd still definitely suggest lowering the tolerance parameter by about 0.1. (making it 0.4). At 0.5 it fits perfectly at first, but it wears down and loosens up a bit.

Feedback is always appreciated.

Update: Printed it in nylon(white), and the tolerances were perfect for my print. If you have a printer with a stringing problem, remember to clean up the part afterwards.

title: Nintendo Switch joy-con grip (now with a rework!)

description.text:
Initial upload: This is a Joy-con grip for the Nintendo Switch' joy cons. I haven't printed it myself so I don't know if it will fit, so print at your own 'risk'!
there are two designs for the nintendo switch logo so you can choose which one you want to use.

April 18th: added reworks of the first two types, i wasnt happy with how the bit in the middle was connected to the sides.

Later that same day: After some helpful commentary of Thingiverse user BlondeEskimo, I reworked them again, as BlondeEskimo told me that the overhang on the rail was too thick. I made the rail 0.3 mm slimmer, and I hope that it will fit now. I'm sorry if you had printed this and it ended up as a failure!

The print in the thumbnail was made by Thingiverse user BlondeEskimo.

let me know if you printed it!
Thanks!

Printer:

Anycubic kossel plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10% or 20%

Notes:

0.2 worked for me, but for finer quality you can also print at 0.1, but that was not tested!
the supports are really needed!

Someone in the comments was talking about their print breaking apart while printing, so i'd advise to print at 30 mm/s, as 60 mm/s might be too fast.

Print took my printer about 2~3 hours
It would be nice if you could upload your makes to thingiverse!

it's not neccesary to do anything after it comes off the print bed, but sandgng isnever a bad idea, just watch out that you don't sand the rails too much on the inside because they might become too looase to hold on to the joy-cons

comments.text: I printed every other joycon holder on here and this is the first one that actually holds the things in place. Great work!

Braille Output

Hallo 3D - Gemeinde,
ich finde die Geschichte um die OpenRC Tractor Entwicklung von Makitpro
(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967086), genial.
Alle Teile, außer dem Motor und der Elektronik lassen sich ausdrucken und wenn dann mal was bricht, relativ schnell wieder ersetzen.
Auch die Mods und das sonstige Zubehör welches Makitpro zur Verfügung stellt ist super.
Was mir aber nicht gefallen hat, ist das der Motor-Mod eine starre durchgehende Achse antreibt, warum ist hier kein Differentialgetriebe vorgesehen?
Das hat mich dazu angetrieben, selber zu schauen, ob sich die Möglichkeit für ein Differential ergeben könnte. Ich habe dazu diverse Teile mit DesignSpark Mechanical nachkonstruiert, um Änderungen in den Aufbau einfließen zu lassen. Dabei sind verschiedene Einzelheiten auf der Strecke geblieben, wie die Anschraubpunkte für den hinteren Heber oder der Anhängevorrichtung, aber diese lassen sich relativ einfach im nach hinein ergänzen. Ich habe versucht, das ursprüngliche Design soweit es ging, bei zu behalten, trotzdem waren einige Änderungen in den Chassis nötig.
Es ist leider auch so, das obwohl ich hier schon einige Versuchsausdrucke gemacht habe, immer noch Änderungspotential vorhanden ist, um zum Beispiel die Lagerung des Motors zu verbessern, ich musste feststellen, dass es beim Motor wohl auch unterschiedliche Längen gibt und damit die hintere Strebe entfallen muss.
Habe ich aber in den Planungen nicht berücksichtig.
Ich kann auch keine Getriebe oder Zahnräder konstruieren, was mich dazu veranlasst hat, hier bei Thingiverse nach den Teilen zu suchen, welche ich benötige. Unter der Adresse www.thingiverse.com/thing:79938 habe ich das nötigte Diferrential gefunden, „barspin“ hat hier ein geschlossenes Differential für den Maßstab 1:10 abgelegt, was mir geeignet erschien. Die Antriebsachsen selbst wurden dann noch neu konstruiert. Das Input_Pinion war leider nicht dabei, dieses fand ich dann unter www.thingiverse.com/thing:737465, allerdings musste hier der Maßstab und die Öffnung für die Motorachse überarbeitet werden.

Zum Aufbau selbst, die beiden Chassis-Teile müssen mit Support und mindestens 55% Füllung ausgedruckt werden, beim Getriebe und den Achsen ist der Support nicht erforderlich, der Ausdruck sollte aber mit 100% Füllung gedruckt werden.
Das Getriebe wird zusätzlich mit zwei Kugellagern der gleichen Größe wie sie bereits an den Achsen zum Einsatz gekommen sind, gelagert. Für den Aufbau des Getriebes sind Senkkopfschrauben der Größe M3x10 gut geeignet, zusätzlich werden noch zwei Senkkopfschrauben für das Verschrauben des Differentialgehäuses benötigt. Wenn vorhanden Schrauben für Kunststoff verwenden, Länge ca. 15mm. Auf die Achsen werden vor Montage der Kugellager, die Spacer aufgesetzt, der kurze Spacer auf die linke, der längere Spacer auf die rechte Seite, diese sollen verhindern, dass das Getriebe im Gehäuse hin und her wandert.
Die Kugellager aufsetzen und die Antriebseinheit ins untere Chassis einsetzen.
Das Input_Pinion auf die Motorachse platzieren, hier ist vermutlich kontrollierte Gewalt nötig, da der Achsdurchmesser größer ist als die Bohrung. Das ist beabsichtigt, weil das Zahnrad sonst durchdreht. Der Motor hat eine fixe Position und wird in diese eingelegt. Die Anschlußdrähte, die natürlich vorher montiert sein müssen, aus dem unteren Chassis herausführen und dann oberes und unteres Chassis verschrauben. Eine zusätzliche Verschraubung hinter dem Motor durch beide Chassisteile hindurch soll zusätzlich Klemmkraft aufbringen.
Wie weiter oben bereits erwähnt, habe den Aufbau schon ein paar Mal gemacht, schon aus der Entwicklung heraus waren einige Probedrucke nötig um die Umsetzbarkeit immer wieder zu überprüfen.
Allerdings ist der Motor (RS540) wohl doch ein bisschen stark für den Antrieb, bei dem Übersetzungsverhältnis das sich aus dem Differential ergibt, wird der Traktor zu einer Rennmaschine, deshalb ist es wohl nötig, einen Sender mit Servowegbegrenzung zu benutzen und dort vernünftige Werte einzustellen.
Meinen Dank an alle die, die mit ihren Beträgen mir dazu unbewusst geholfen haben, dieses Projekt umzusetzen und ganz besonderen Dank an Makitpro, der diesen OpenRC Gedanken gestartet hat.

Hello 3D community,
I find the story around the OpenRC Tractor development of Makitpro (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1967086) , awesome.
All parts, except the engine and the electronics can be printed and if then something breaks, relatively quickly replace again.
Also the mods and the other accessories makitpro provides is great.
What I did not like, however, is that the engine mod drives a rigid continuous axis, why is there no differential gear provided?
This has prompted me to see for myself whether the possibility of a differential could arise. I have reconstructed various parts with DesignSpark mechanical to allow changes to be incorporated into the design. There are various details on the route, such as the mounting points for the rear jack or the hitch, but these can be relatively easy to supplement. I tried to keep the original design as far as I could, but some modifications were necessary in the chassis.
It is unfortunately synonymous, although I have already made some trial expressions, still change potential is present, for example, the storage of the engine to improve, I had to find that the engine probably synonymous different lengths and thus the rear strut Must be omitted.
I have however in the plans not considered.
I can not construct gears, which has caused me to search here at Thingiverse for the parts I need. Under the address www.thingiverse.com/thing:79938 I have found the necessary diferrential, "barspin" has filed here a closed differential for the scale 1:10, which seemed suitable for me. The drive axles themselves were then newly designed. The Input_Pinion was unfortunately not there, I found then under www.thingiverse.com/thing:737465, however, the scale and the opening for the engine axis had to be reworked here.

For the assembly itself, the two chassis parts must be printed with support and at least 55% filling, the gear and the axles do not require support, but the print should be printed with 100% filling.
The gearbox is additionally supported with two ball bearings of the same size as those already used on the axles. For the design of the gearbox, countersunk head screws of size M3x10 are well suited, in addition, two countersunk head screws are required for screwing the differential housing. If available, use screws for plastic, length approx. 15mm. The spacers are placed on the axles before mounting the ball bearings, the short spacers on the left, the longer spacers on the right side, which are intended to prevent the gearbox from moving back and forth in the housing.
Place the ball bearing and insert the drive unit into the lower chassis.
Place the Input_Pinion on the motor axis, presumably controlled force is required, since the axle diameter is larger than the bore. This is because the gear wheel rotates otherwise. The motor has a fixed position and is inserted into it. The connecting wires, which must be installed before, must be removed from the lower chassis and then screw the upper and lower chassis. An additional screw connection behind the motor through both chassisteiles should additionally apply clamping force.
As already mentioned above, the design has already been done a few times, already from the development were some Probedrucke necessary in order to check the feasibility again and again.
However, the engine (RS540) is probably a bit strong for the drive, with the gear ratio resulting from the differential, the tractor becomes a racing machine, so it is necessary to use a transmitter with servo limit and set reasonable values .
My thanks to all those who, with their amounts, helped me unconsciously to implement this project and very special thanks to Makitpro, who started this OpenRC thought.

comments.author: JR_Jae

comments.text: I wish the individual pieces looked different, similar to the original game. Was there a constraint preventing that from happening?
comments.author: unreal_ed

comments.text:
I designed the pieces to be small and to easily fit them in a box, so the final dimensions remain useful for a portable game.
The original game has different sizes and designs for each floor, which would make more difficult to fit in a box that size.
comments.author: unreal_ed

comments.text: I think it's better if the pieces are all the same: less searching for the right piece, and less danger of running out of a piece type (the game is supposed to have infinite pieces, I understand).
comments.author: JR_Jae

comments.text: This is perfect just as it is thank you! Uniformity among the pieces is a GREAT way to go for a portable game, keeps from having to fish around for specific pieces when you don't have the room.  Thank you again for a great build and i'd love to see more from you!
comments.author: JR_Jae

comments.text: I don't see why you couldn't just make some of the pieces smaller but just shaped differently. It's not like when they're in the box they fit telescopically (or at least it definitely doesn't look like it on the photo), so whatever shape the other pieces have shouldn't matter as long as they stay inside the volume of the current pieces.
comments.author: JR_Jae

title: GEEETech i3X: X-2-B/C Upgrade Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
in the GEEETech Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series the X version is the entry level one, with acrylic idler where the B and C version now have the metal ones… but before they had printed ones!
Unfortunately the X version have 27mm distance between bars where B and C have 22mm, so owner of X cannot buy the Metal upgrade kit!
With my X-2-B/C kit now owner of i3 can print brand new idler, carriage and extruder holder to quite transform their i3X in a i3B, the mono extruder version, or i3C, the dual extruder version.
The two idler, also if they look like the old printed ones of i3B/C, have now 27mm clearance between bars, the end stop support and x motor center aligned with i3X ones!
In addition to the new idler I’ve also refurbished carriage and extruder holder in order to integrate some good idea GEEETech have introduced in metal component:

1.New X-Belt fixing, really more easy to use compared to old one
2.X-End Stop regulation 
3.Holes to unmounts motors for dual version
4.Nut space on extruder holder where screw add-on

The original i3X X-Motor idler have the motor inverted compared to i3B/C, and this part share the motor in the i3B/C position, so you have to reversein the firmware the sense of rotation, is easy, just find the row “#define INVERT_X_DIR” and put true if you find false or vice versa, nothing other!

PS: Unfortunately I wasn’t able to reuse the linear bearing that i3X have in idler and carriage and must be replaced with the LM8LUU linear bearing that was originally designed for i3B/C component.

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

title: GEEETech i3X (ACRYLIC version): Single Extruder FAN & LED
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
following my implementation on GEEETech i3 Pro series I’ve given a look to the entry level one, the i3X with original acrylic idler!
Here the Extruder FAN & LED component of my customization in i3X version!
The i3X version have the same identical features of the i3B/C one, so duct for MK8 fan, 3DTouch place, led holder and a cooler fan!
For 3DTouch setup the position, based on cad data, you can use:

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -29
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -39
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -2.58

As usual in all my design I’ve split all in order to have an easy print of each, and also an easy mounting after print!

PS: after the installation of this customization is a good Idea to re-execute the PID Autotest!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

comments.text:
Hi,
on my i3B I’ve started with the plastics idlers and 30mm barrel… in this configuration I’ve never have extruder issue but at this time I’ve also the metallic feeder!
When I’ve move from plastic to metal idlers I’ve forced to move also from 30mm to 38mm barrel and I start to have some extruder issue or, better, some barrel clogging issue… but I’ve also change the feeder from metal one to the new, black, plastic one.
Now I have my reviewed plastic feeder and 38mm barrel and all look fine, but I do not know if is for better firmware setting, better slicer setting or for the feeder!

description.text:
I've printed this and it is working.
Altho you'll have to make your bow hang on to the machine by yourself
designed for Nema17 on all axis, 8mm verticals and 25mm horizontals (because them are free for me) and M8 threaded rod with M8-nuts pressed into the carriages.

I have some binding issues, probably due to alligning the bearings and aligning the nuts.
I am thinking about redesigning for bushings instead.

Since the photo was taken i have moved the drivers to inside the case and use DB9 and ethernet cables for motors.
5th Axis i have not used yet (17/03/25)

non-plastic parts is:

  • 4 lm8uu bearings.
  • 8mm verticals.
  • 4-8 lm25uu bearings (i use 8).
  • 25mm horizontals.
  • Nema17 motors.
  • Sterpper-Drivers.
  • M8 nuts + threaded rods
  • M3-screws for assembly
  • 22mm skateboardtype bearings for passive sides.

title: Lasercut Stackable Miniature and Other Storage For Ikea Expedit or Kallax
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My storage solution for miniatures or other collections, which fits neatly into my existing Ikea Expedit or Kallax storage shelves/bookcases (13" x 13" x 1 1/2" deep). Designed for easy carrying and to hold modest amounts of weight, in case you still use lead miniatures. The provided templates have a blank space that you might fill with other cutting patterns and are designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can customize them at your own leisure with labels and text as demonstrated in the pictures provided. I have also included one template with deep and one template with shallow dividers as meets your requirement or preference (see pictures). Inspired by a smaller micro armor stackable storage solution I saw on someone's blog.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size, which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

The pictured dust cover is also available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208729

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text:
Revised Smoothie board mount with hex holes to reduce filament needed when printed solid or with infill.
I also reduced the amount of polys, looks just as good but will take a lot less time to slice.

description.text:
I noticed that carriages that came with my Kossel Mini kit had a design flaw which caused a slight twisting of the carriages. Unfortunately I couldn't find any designs that suit my needs and I had to make one of my own.

This is a replacement for the original carriages, so all the holes and dimensions are matching for easy upgrade.

It would be awesome to use with this type of arm holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1598591

Printer:

Kossel Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

50%

• 3x printed parts
  • 9x 19mm rollers (https://goo.gl/NNKYCp)
  • 9x 25mm M6 countersunk bolts
  • 3x 15mm M3 bolts (6x if you are planning to use endstop adjustment screws)
  • 9x 5mm M3 bolts
  • 12x M3 nuts (15x if you are planning to use endstop adjustment screws)
  • 3x 10x3mm magnets (https://goo.gl/m4xO5W)
This is a upgrade for that type of carriage, but it may work with other designs too.

Print out all the required parts.

Mount two of the wheels and tighten them up nicely. I used 30mm M6 countersunk crosshead bolts because my local hardware store did not have any other options. Although I would recommend to use allen type countersunk bolts.Leave the third wheel unassembled to simplify the mounting of the carriages.

Slide M3 nut to its place and add an adjustment screw. Do not apply any tension to the adjustment screw at this point.

If you are using classical mechanical endstops then you can go with the configuration on the left or if you have hall endstops then there are a snuggly fit for 10x3mm magnets.

Add M3 bolts for fixing the arm holder to the carriage.

Mount the carriages to the frame and tighten all the M6 bolts.

Mount the arm holder

Adjust the adjustment screw and you're done!

two bishops
two knights
two rooks
eight pawns connect head to king and king to queen..
assemble hands and legs in any order you like to create your own chess bot

It's better to print the figures in 120..150% scale. Rooks and bishops are better to be printed in horizontal position. Bishop could be substituted by two head-to-tail connected pawns King and Queen are tend to each other, hovewer you might connect them in different ways creating non humanoid bodies. there are many ways of connecting figures into combinations:
for instance, even two pawns can be connected in two different ways (head to tail, and tail to tail) at the same time each figure can be connected:
pawns and knigts with two other figures
rooks, bishops and queen with three other figures
king with four pairs which could not be connected directly are:
knigt and rook
queen and knigt

author: Hkdasb

description.text:
Educational gear cutting
Gears are usually made milling with a tool. The the gear in this project is created by virtual milling with a virtual tool. (As opposed to the standard gear creation in CAD programs that directly extrude a gear that is calculated by formulas).

The attached file is written in Lua that can be interpreted and rendered by IceSL. It's not compatible to OpenSCAD (IceSL renderes in real-time, there are no extra buttons to preview or render). It produces an involute gear, with a few steps:
-Prepare a raw cylinder to be milled (blank, not rendered per default, color red)
-Prepare the milling tool, a trapezoid (Tool, raw)
-Prepare a shifted tool (Tool, shifted)
-Prepare a complex tool (Tool, complex)
-Display the gear

The 'raw' tool would be very thin, and it would be moved perpendicular to the cylinder, cutting two tooth flanks at once. These flanks would have the exact same shape as the tool, i.e. they would be straight. Additionally the cylinder is rotated slowly in one direction while the tool is moved along a tangent of the cylinder in the same direction. This changes one tooth flank, giving it an involute shape.

In the program I've taken another approach to simplify the teeth creation:
The raw tool has the same width as the gear, eliminating the need for perpendicular movement. Based on that 'raw' tool a 'shifted' tool is created: That 'shifted' tool is based on the 'raw' tool by adding shifted and rotated samples of the raw tool - just the same way as if it was moved along a tangent of the cylinder while rotating the cylinder. Using this 'shifted' tool it is possible to cut two tooth flanks with a single operation, without the need to rotate the cylinder. The slider 'Shift in %' makes it possible to change the shift in real time and see the effect on 'shifted' tool and the resulting gear.

Then the 'shifted' tool is cloned a few times into a 'complex' tool that is used to cut all teeth at once, and the gear is done.

The source offers a few more things to tweak, like helical, herringbone or arc teeth forms...feel free to play with it...have fun!

Source for IceSL:
https://members.loria.fr/Sylvain.Lefebvre/icesl/
It's biggest advantage over OpenSCAD - real-time rendering - is also it's biggest disadvantage, as it requires on a modern graphics card. There's also a WebGL-based version available, which I cannot recommend for this very complex script (much too slow due to javascript and WebGL overhead). Scripting documentation for IceSL:
https://gforge.inria.fr/plugins/mediawiki/wiki/icesl/index.php/Scripting Lua:
https://www.lua.org/ Required graphic cards:
[tested] GeForce GTX 480 / 580 / 680 / 970 / Titan
[tested] GeForce GT 555M
[tested] Intel HD 4400, 4600
[tested] AMD Radeon 290X (with limitations)
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8q4DUdhPP7q

title: Customizable Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU, LM8LUU, LM12UU, LM12LUU, LM16UU, ...  IGUS like

description.text:
With this customizable design, you are able to create bushings, that will be printed in an optimal way. You can set the inner and outer diameter, the length, the extrusion width, number of perimeters and number of teeth.
You can find a more detailed description above each variable in the MakerBot Customizer or OpenSCAD file.
Please leave a comment, if you have any questions or problems!

Updates

  • 2018-02-15: Groove settings added.
  • 2018-01-09: fixed inner diameter. Thanks to kerusursaone!
  • 2017-12-21: added chamfer angle option.
  • 2017-10-02: I still can't recognize any wear to the bushings. I seasoned the bushings a second time with PTFE spray (this time from WD-40), just to be sure.
  • 2017-08-15: partial fixed graphic glitch in customizer, if you are setting a chamfer
  • 2017-08-07: added chamfer setting in customizer. There will be a graphic glitch in the preview, but the .stl-File will be generated without any glitch.
  • 2017-06-14: After 3 months and 4kg filament, i couldn't recognize any wear to these bushings, printed in PLA. I used one drop PTFE oil per bearing in the beginning and the bushings are still wet. For me, they perform much better, than the IGUS Japan bushings.

How to support me?

Do you like my things and do you want to support me? You can use these links if you want to buy something. This helps me doing more things. Thanks!

Banggood: https://goo.gl/ZXgx3A
Gearbest: https://goo.gl/FfE59f
Aliexpress: https://goo.gl/bQLi15

Printer:

Anet A8

Resolution:

0.12

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Extrusion width (not the nozzle size!) and # of perimeters should be in sync between the Customizer / OpenSCAD and your Slicer! Check the 4th picture how it should look like, before printing.

Best way in my case is to choose the bushing where you can push it in with some effort on the rod and slide it by hand without any tools. Then slide it back and forth along the rod, until the bushing has the expected behavior. I suggest you not to use any drill or heat. The sliding of the bushing generates enough heat from its friction against the rod.

Website

https://mightynozzle.com

comments.text:
What is the advantage of custom layer heights?
I mean, why 0.12mm instead of 0.1mm or 0.2mm?
I ask because the last time I printed individual layer heights, I had gaps between some layers.
comments.author: ikarisan

comments.text:
This is not a custom layer height. Maybe your slicer suggest these .1 steps.
A regular stepper motor has 200 full steps per revolution (1.8°/step). With a T8x8 lead screw, the Z-carriage moves 8mm per turn. So one full-step is 0.04mm (8mm/200). This is, why I only use the multiply of 0.04mm --> 0.08, 0.12, 0.16, 0.2, etc.. I've the best experience with these layer heights.
comments.author: ikarisan

comments.text: Ah, okay. My Anet A8 uses T8x1.5 lead screws. So the optimized layer high is 0.1mm or 0.2mm
comments.author: mightynozzle

comments.text: No, the Anet A8 uses a T8x8 --> one turn = 8mm travel. You can simply check it, by marking the screw or rod, travel 8mm very slow in the z-axis and count how many times the mark passes (=1 time).

comments.author: sayedali

comments.text: I don't have Cura installed. But if your slicer has a preview option, you should check the perimeter as you can see in the 4th picture. It is important, that the extrusion width and perimeter is the same as in your slicer. You don't want any infill, because this can destroy the round shape of the bushing. Only use perimeter without gaps between it. For layer height, you should choose the smallest possible, s.th. between 0.08 and 0.20mm. Temperature and speed depends on the filament and hotend/extruder.

comments.author: HikariNoKitsune

comments.text: The Igus are designed to be used with the right sized smooth rod eg. 8mm h7  and for the low profile one to be press fitted. In that case there is virtually no play. Igus clerly document the way it must be mounted for best results.
comments.author: mightynozzle

comments.text:
My rods are h6 smoothed and hardened steel rods from https://www.dold-mechatronik.de/Praezisionswelle-8mm-h6-geschliffen-und-gehaertet-ZUSCHNITT-bis-1200mm-1300-EUR-m-025-EUR-pro-Schnitt
But the RJ4JP-01-08 are to loose + they stuck on the rod (they don't move alone throw gravity). The whole X-Idler segment will wobble against the bushing and will cause more tolerance in the x and y axis. This might be no problem in the y axis, or maybe not in the x axis, but the problem will be the z-axis of a Prusa i3-like printer. But the printed one flies over the rod and have no noticable play.
About the wearing I will use some PTFE or machine oil. This should prevent some heat through friction. I see, that you also have some IGUS-style designs. Do you use any kind of lubrication?
I will also try print some bushings with iglidur filament from IGUS. I have three samples from them to test. But I don't think that they are better than PLA. These are advertised to be stronger as ABS and they should be printed like ABS.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I don't use any lubrication.
I don't have any wobble because first I eliminated its cause. All my bearings are of my own made with Igus filament. I kept the Z linear ball bearings but replaced the SS smooth rod by hardened one of the correct size. The play then is minimal (0.05) thus vibrations due to the X carriage high acceleration have no effect and no binding at all while with polymer bushings because of the impossibility to perfectly align the two Z smooth rods on a Prusa frame, there could lead to some binding. In fact to validate some ideas I had, I removed the two smooth rods and just used the lead screw (TR8 whose quality surprised me) as lead screw and guide using specially designed Igus nuts (no play, no backlash). It was working, but I had to drive my Z motor to the max because of this lack of // leading to extra friction. Would work with a better frame, more rigid, box type. I am looking at it but for an other kind of set up than the Prusa.
Even the bearings of the idler are made with Igus filament and running on Aluminum 4mm bar, same for a bearing in my extruder. Indeed Igus bearings run well on anodized Al. In fact too smooth a rod is not advisable.
The advantage in this hobby is that by making one's own bearings we can perfectly match them like in the old days, reaming, scraping, burnishing.
comments.author: mightynozzle

Remix of the great laptop model by cymon and added a tactile mouse and split the mouse keys then added the Thingiverse logo model extruded out of the screen. Have been thinking about ways to illustrate digital fabrication and this came to mind. Also added the clean laptop model with just the additions made to the keyboard.

If this is in violation of branding - copyright, etc in any way please delete it. I just love the fact that Thingiverse is so incredibly valuable in 3d modeling and printing so thought it would be fitting. I am printing the 1st attempt so there may be some tweaks - particularly for the lettering overhang. I might make one using the TinkerCAD logo as well since it is also an amazing tool for beginners like me.

Kossel mini

No

No

0,2

Notes:
  1. Spiralize countour in cura.
  2. Checkout solid top infill.
  3. Set top/bottom thickness near 2mm.
  4. Set shell thickness about 2 x nozzle (0.4X2=0.8).
  5. Turn off infill density.
A piece of cloth thrown at the ball and cutted.

comments.text: Great vase, thank you.  Printed one in marble effect Ziro pla on my CR-10.
comments.author: DarkwingUK

comments.text:
Beautiful vase, thanks for this model. I printed it in translucid green PLA, awesome.
I have a question regarding the instructions: I'm using Cura 3.1.0 and could not change the Wall Thickness in spiral mode. Well, I could, but it had no impact on the slicing; that make sense, I do not know how the slicer could print two layers in spiral mode without a visible jonction. I tried with or without the spiral smoothing option.
Just in case, is it possible to make the wall stronger in spiral mode?
comments.author: cr1cr1

comments.text: Spiral mode overrides many other settings so it has to be single wall. You can increase some other things like bottom layers.
comments.author: cr1cr1

description.text:
This is a simple air plug for an inflatable toy. It is a measured duplicate of one used for a particular toy, but is customizable so that it should work for other toys.
The openscad source is very short and so should be a good introduction to openscad.

I re-did this project on Fusion 360 and included the source file.
The bulge is slightly different, because scaling does not work the same in Fusion 360 as it does in openscad. I also changed the length of the small section to not include the beveled part.
I tried to put all the dimensions you could edit down the right side of the sketch, and the ones that are calculated down the left side.

description.text: This is a VR viewer that can be used even with the smallest printers, e.g. makerbot mini. you can scale it up if needed for a bigger phone. google carboard lenses are required, but a strap is not. lens size: 25mm.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

regular

Infill:

diamond

POST PRINT

if you see any extra raft material on the print, just cut it off with an exacto knife.

MY INSPIRATION/DRIVE

about 5 months ago, i wanted a VR viewer that didn't cost much at all. I was at the time using a makerbot mini, and i had limited materials and build space. I decided i was up for the challenge and got to work. I know this has been done before, but i thought it would be cool to make my own.
This is essentially the final product, printed on makerbot mini (normal settings, PLA).

description.text:
Three wheeled robot, rear stepper for drive, micro servo steers and directs ultrasonic sensor. Tires utilise under sink s bend replacement seals (Plumbing spares). This project utilises Arduino Nano as the processor and two 18650 batteries for the power. I have this robot running a simple search routine that gets it around many a room without getting stuck. It drives well on carpet and tiles. All files are designed to print without supports. You will need to rotate them in your slicer. PLA works well I have not used any other material for the print. I am using this robot to teach STEM: 3d printing, design and programming.

UPDATE:
V2 Lid allows the use of Nokia Screen for output of ultrasonic readings.

Instructions for building will follow....

If you have sagging light covers in your office or home, this will prevent the light cover from creeping its way out of the housing and smashing into the floor.
The thinner piece goes in against the cover so that the gap between the cover and the housing is the smallest.

print_settings.Notes:: There are some small supports on the bottom that need to be broken, plus some small supports that will be broken by a putty knife between the blocks.

description.text:
I rewrote a lot of the openscad to get rid of most of the magic numbers so that it could be customizable. I also added a few things to make it easier to print.
You still need a putty knife to break apart the blocks once it is done.
It turns fairly well, but still catches quite a bit. I am not sure what is catching on what, so I am unsure how this can be fixed.
I can see several improvements I could make, but it takes almost 13 hours to print on my FlashForge Creator Pro so I kind of gave up after committing one long weekend to the project.
Note that it is a slight extra challenge above just solving a Rubiks cube, because you have to also get the letters the right way around.

I recently got an Assassins Creed backpack which I love dearly.
Getting and keeping it closed was an awkward thing, though.
The upper end is to be rolled up and the strap over it was held in place with a
velcro strap which got weak early. Heavily laden with all the food I need at work
it always came loose once I had it on my back and took a breath.

This buckle replaces the velcro, snaps smooth in place and is released by turning
the outer ring some 60° to the left.

Additionally needed is
6 x M3 nuts and screws (8-10 mm, depending on the thickness of your belt or whatever)
4 x spiral springs from a ballpen

Print all parts and two of the latches with 0,1 mm and 20% infill which prooved
to be quite sturdy. All parts are printing well without supports. Only for the buckle you
need to determine yourself whether you want to place some supports (I had), but even there is enough give for bridings. Take care that you have your printer dialed in well, all tolerances between moving parts are only 0,1 mm.
It is up to you whether you want to print just the lid with the embossed blackbird shape
or use the attached inlay (raised) for dual print.
Smoothing some edges with fine sandpaper is required to have all the
parts working together perfectly.

Use glue (my favorite is styrofoam) to fix the base to its place on the outside.
Puncture the holes. Longer screws could be of help to fix the inner plate with
glue if wanted. Put base and inner plate together with nuts and bolts. Do it likewise
with the buckle, belt and outer plate. Place the latches in the base and put the springs in.
The latter can be a pain in the ass...
One of mine popped out and was lost. We have a granite-stone floor and whatever falls
down ( no matter if nuts, screws, pieces of filament) is lost forever...
At least until one of our pugs comes with it in its muzzle using it as chow...
The springs successfully placed just assemble the lid and you are ready to go.
https://youtu.be/wiNckRls91o

This is my DIY (Design It Yourself) + DIY (Do It Yourself) + PIY (Print It Yourself) Project.

Project - Toothbrush Port (Container)

This is a variation on the 2x4 Fidget cube.
This is one of my most popular 3D prints, it is amazing how many people like this. It can also be a baby toy.
No assembly required.
Recommend you print with support from the base plate only.
There are some overhangs that I might be able to do something about, but for the most part it prints, then a little bit of cracking sound as you bend it the first few times, and then it is very smooth.
I designed this in OpenScad because I wanted to add text to the cube. If you don't have a dual extruder then simply set the textFill to 0 and the text will show up as an indentation on the cube. If you don't want any text then set the textFill to 2. textFill to 1.
Text means this can be used as a promotional give away, or an advertisement. One neat thing about the text is that the part of the text that shows up on the hinge pins will always be correctly oriented when the cube is in the correct orientation. Capital letters and short text are recommended as the gaps between the cubes can make the text difficult to read if it is too small.

title: raspberry pi 3 mobile console (xbox 360 controller mount)

description.text:
This is a complete case and Xbox 360 controller mount for a Raspberry Pi 3 and the official 7" Raspberry Pi Touchscreen.
This case will allow you to easily mount your raspberry pi 3 on a xbox 360 controller for retro gaming on the go, or dismount your raspberry and make it a stationery console which can connect to a bigger monitor.
The case can also stand on his own if you prefer to put it on a table.
The case allows full access to all of the raspberry's ports (no access to the microSD card though).

I added a file illustrating how it should look when mounting on a controller, unfortunately I could not print this myself, duo to the fact I don't currently own a 3D printer, so if you print this please kip in mind that this print is completely untested and may fit perfectly on the controller. If you have any problems with this print please let me know.

The files named "controller attachment" and "connector" should be a bit more flexible, so print them with low infill percentage.
The file named "case_holder" will need to be printed with supports.
All of the other parts print settings are yours to choose, although I don't think they will require support or raft.

I would love some feedback if you have any.

UPDATE (01.04.2017): addaed two new cases wich add the option to add a battery adafruit's Powerboost 1000c lithium ion battery charger to make this a truly mobile console. The first case ("raspberry and battery case") is ment to replace the previous one, It is bigger then the original, but allowes you to add a small battery, a switch, and a Powerboost 1000c charger. I don't belive it will fit anything bigger then Adafruit's 4400mah lithium ion battery (not sure if even this will fit in it).
The second case ("battery case") is an add on to the original one, it is a separate compartment which can be screwed on top of the original case, in it there is room for the Powerboost 1000c chager, a small switch to turn the console on and off, and enough room for a large 6600mah Adafruit battery.
I also changed some of the original files so they would be easier to manage and print.

Resolution:

0.1mm>

Infill:

30-50

all screws should be size M3.
you will need a good rubber band.

first secure the screen and the raspberry in the case, and only then put the battery and charger in. if you are using the "raspberry and battery case" make sure the battery has enough room.
the "battery case" will screw on top of the the "raspberry case".

for instructions on how to connect the battery and charger go to:
https://learn.adafruit.com/7-portable-raspberry-pi-multitouch-tablet

for instructions on how the "case holder" works go to:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1991267

for instructions on how to connect the mount to the controller go to:
https://learn.adafruit.com/3d-printed-personal-monitor-game-controller-mount/3d-printing?view=all

title: Anycubic Kossel Calibration Coaxial Sensor Holder

description.text:
if you need permament sensor holder, check this thing:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203930

This is M12 inductive sensor holder which is designed to be mounted in place of blower nozzle with original M2 screws. The sensor position is perfectly under the nozzle so the measurement is not affected by non-linear delta kinematics. Use it to calibrate your DELTA printer with help of escher calculator (http://www.escher3d.com/pages/wizards/wizarddelta.php).
With repetier firmware you can set your sensor 3mm above the bed and then probe with G30 P0 command. Returned Z values copy to corresponding cells in ESCHER calculator.

I recommend this order of calibration which gave me perfect results:

  1. Find the center of the printer with repetier method in this clip:
    https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9URtv2LqKc
    end at 1:45 min DO NOT USE G32 S2 AT THIS MOMENT, now you have some initial settings which can be used as an input to DELTA calculator. You can use my G-CODE to automate this process a little bit, you should have working sensor already mounted to use G-CODE.
  2. Use ESCHER calculator at least twice. In files you can find my G-CODE which automates z-probing. Adjust the point coordinates to your own if you need.
  3. NOW USE G32 S2 with the probe mounted below the nozzle (remember to set measuring points and nozzle offset which should be X0, Y0, Z0)
  4. Dismount the sensor holder and correct the Z MAX HEIGHT setting to be relative to your hotend nozzle. (use sheet of paper method or place your sensor in my another holder http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203930)

In my case distortion correction messed up my calibration so I had to do everything again so I don't use it.

Later on I will possibly make more "step by step" guide

This print will need supports. I printed this model with the top side UP and used Slic3r generated supports. It turned out good. I initially planned to print upside down which is why the STL defaults to that position. That might be a better orientation honestly.

description.text:
Saw what was done to the original but i found that i did not want both fans going all the time because it lowered my temp by 10 degrees C. So i threw it into 123D real quick and created a hole the same size as the first switch, and got rid of the LED light because who needs to see that its on if its so damn loud?

Buy a second switch- all items linked in orginal.
THANK YOU!

Davinci pro 1.0
Layer height .2mm
Normal 2
Top surface 3
bottom 3
infill 15%

~Speed~27mm/s

No raft/Brim/support

description.text:
This will replace the Ashtray in your Classic Mini.
--Box--
Use six M2.5 x 15mm screws to attach the front to the main Box. Here you will also need to cut the thread into the Box.
--Slider--
Use one M3 x 15mm screw to attach the small slider to the box. Best to use a locknut from below. Not to tight so that it slides in and out easy.
Use three M4 x 10mm screws to attach the Phone Holder to the Slider. In the Slider you need to cut an M4 thread.
To connect the two sliders i used a cut of peace of 3mm Filament.
-- Mount to Mini --
Once assembled push the slider in all the way and mount the box to you Mini.
Done!

I only have an iPhone so i only made an iPhone holder. You can create your own adapter to suit your Phone. The three mounting screws are 15mm apart.

A Spin off EMPY BOX is also available:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2207925

RF1000

comments.text: If you wanted to get complicated, you could have the bottom of the phone holding section hinged and flip down as well. Make it a two step process. Flip the main part down, then the bottom section, then insert your phone. The bottom, when flipped down, would have the current shelf the phone rests on with access to the charger port, and when flipped up would place the door in the correct orientation to cover the box when stowed. (if that makes any sense)

title: Dual mosfet modul for 12V PSU, 16A connectors, Prusa i3, A6 A8 A2

description.text:
Since no perfect fit for my preferences in the mosfet question, I designed my own dual mosfet modul. It work flawlessly :)
Mine is ready, but got plenty of extra pcb-s, so if you are interested, send me a message.

Main features:

  • 2 channels for hotbed and hotend
  • high quality mosfet's, no heatsink needed
  • minimal wiring required
  • directly bolted to the PSU, minimalized power path and power loss
  • polarity of the signals doesn't matter
  • 16A power connectors

For the fets you need a hot air soldering station.

http://www.ebay.com/itm/3D-printer-dual-mosfet-modul-12V-PSU-16A-connectors-Prusa-i3-A6-A8-A2-/272642529100?hash=item3f7ac2d74c:g:T6kAAOSwdGFYzu30

title: Star Wars Clone Trooper Phase 2 Armor

description.text:
This is a remix of MasterDarkOnyx Trooper that is more simple so it prints with way less supports. My modifications:

  1. Tucked in some of the armor closer to the body that was creating overhangs. Tucking them in reduced the amount of supports drastically.
  2. Changed out the complex gun for a for a simple DC-15. The DC-15 is positioned in a way that will print very clean since it is vertical. The DC-15 also serves as a sturdy support, which again makes the print more stable and requires less supports.
  3. Changed the complex fingers to fists.
  4. Changed out the helmet to a Phase 2 helmet

I also resized it to print at 3.75 inch action figure size.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7aa47vwCE90

This is mount for GoPro-like case to NVG mount (rhino mount) on helmets.
Suitable for airsoft usage.

There are two versions - Low and High.
High version provides more "like from eyes" view when you're playing hot CQB.
Low version more suitable for outdoor games.

Completely toolless design. No furniture needed - only basic case screw.

Outer (O) part should be printed up from it's base.
Inner (I) part should be printed up from it's back edge.
